creator: seade@apache.org
text:
The FunctionHelper class searches for Function implementations in lib/ext rather
than the classpath.  This makes it difficult to work on the JMeter source as
undesirable behavour occurs when both the jar files and the class files exist
under lib/ext.

creator: dbreese@qwest.com
text:
I agree.  My application has literally 100's of jar files and running under 
Weblogic.  I created my own jmeter.sh startup script so it can use my 
classpath, but JMeter appearantly completely ignores my classpath.  Instead, I 
have to end up copying all my jar files, EJBs, weblogic, etc into the lib 
directory.  It would be nice if jmeter would do just like most other apps and 
search the classpath you give it and not a hard-coded directory structure.  
Basically, the classpath below provides no value: 
#!/bin/bash
JMETER_CMD_LINE_ARGS=$*
java -classpath "$CLASSPATH" -jar ApacheJMeter.jar $JMETER_CMD_LINE_ARGS

The -cp and -classpath switches are (silently) ignored by the java command if 
the -jar switch is used. Likewise for the CLASSPATH environment variable. 

This is the documented behaviour (but may not be explained in all reference 
books) - it is not JMeter that is ignoring the classpath, it is the JVM.

One work-round is to add ApacheJMeter.jar to the classpath and specify the 
main class explicitly - i.e. org.apache.jmeter.NewDriver.
